summary: This document is a series of emails from September 16-17, 2020, between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) and Department of Justice (DOJ) personnel discussing coordination for a meeting with victims of Jeffrey Epstein. The meeting is a requirement of the DOJ's settlement in the CVRA (Crime Victims' Rights Act) litigation, intended to present the findings of an OPR (Office of Professional Responsibility) investigation. The emails focus on updating victim contact lists and logistical planning to avoid substantive discussions of victims' experiences during the main meeting.

events.title: DOJ Victim Meeting for CVRA Settlement
events.description: The Department of Justice is organizing a meeting in Washington, D.C., with victims of Jeffrey Epstein to explain and review the findings of an OPR investigation, as required by the settlement in the CVRA litigation.

events.title: Nolle Prosequi (Case Dismissal) Proceeding
events.description: Reference to a proceeding in August 2019 where the government's case against Epstein was dropped (nolle prosequi), following which a victim list was generated.

locations: U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The DOJ is required to hold a victim meeting as part of its settlement in the CVRA litigation related to the Epstein case.
The meeting's purpose is to present the findings of an OPR (Office of Professional Responsibility) investigation to victims.
Officials are working to update a victim contact list originally generated in August 2019, acknowledging that the FBI likely has a larger, more current list.
Planners are taking steps to ensure the main meeting does not become a forum for substantive discussion of victims' experiences, offering private FBI agent meetings instead.
The correspondence reveals coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY), ODAG (Office of the Deputy Attorney General), OPR, and FBI victim services.
